title: Ludwig Finscher
text:
Ludwig Finscher (14 March 193030 June 2020) was a German musicologist. He was a professor of <a href="music%20history">music history</a> at the <a href="University%20of%20Heidelberg">University of Heidelberg</a> from 1981 to 1995 and editor of the encyclopedia "<a href="Die%20Musik%20in%20Geschichte%20und%20Gegenwart">Die Musik in Geschichte und Gegenwart</a>". He is respected internationally as an authority on the history of <a href="Classical%20music">Western Classical music</a> from the 16th century to <a href="contemporary%20classical%20music">contemporary classical music</a>, with a view on music in cultural, social, historical and philosophical context, in a clear language for both specialists and lay readers.
Life and career.
Born in <a href="Kassel">Kassel</a>, the youngest of five siblings, Finscher studied <a href="musicology">musicology</a>, English, German and philosophy at the <a href="University%20of%20G%C3%B6ttingen">University of Göttingen</a> from 1949 to 1954. Students at the same time included <a href="Gerhard%20Croll">Gerhard Croll</a>, <a href="Carl%20Dahlhaus">Carl Dahlhaus</a> and <a href="Rudolf%20Stephan">Rudolf Stephan</a>. He earned a <a href="doctorate">doctorate</a> with a thesis about the <a href="Mass%20%28music%29">mass</a>es and <a href="motet">motet</a>s by <a href="Loyset%20Comp%C3%A8re">Loyset Compère</a>, with advisor <a href="Rudolf%20Gerber">Rudolf Gerber</a>. From 1954, he worked for the <a href="Deutsches%20Volksliedarchiv">Deutsches Volksliedarchiv</a> (German archive of folk songs) in <a href="Freiburg%20im%20Breisgau">Freiburg im Breisgau</a>. He returned to Göttingen in 1955, working as a freelance journalist and music critic. He became a scientific assistant to <a href="Walter%20Wiora">Walter Wiora</a> in 1960, first at the <a href="University%20of%20Kiel">University of Kiel</a> and from 1965 at the <a href="University%20of%20Saarbr%C3%BCcken">University of Saarbrücken</a>. In 1967 he obtained his <a href="habilitation">habilitation</a> in Saarbrücken with the work "Das klassische Streichquartett und seine Grundlegung durch Joseph Haydn" (The classical <a href="string%20quartet">string quartet</a> and its foundation by <a href="Joseph%20Haydn">Joseph Haydn</a>). From 1968 to 1981, he held a chair for musicology at the <a href="Goethe%20University%20Frankfurt">University of Frankfurt</a>, and from 1981 until his retirement in 1995 the same position at the <a href="University%20of%20Heidelberg">University of Heidelberg</a>.
Finscher was president of the <a href="Gesellschaft%20f%C3%BCr%20Musikforschung">Gesellschaft für Musikforschung</a> (Society for music research) from 1974 to 1977 and the <a href="International%20Musicological%20Society">International Musicological Society</a> from 1977 to 1981.
He died in <a href="Wolfenb%C3%BCttel">Wolfenbüttel</a> on 30 June 2020 at the age of 90.
Research work.
One of Finscher's most important accomplishments was his editing, beginning in 1994, of the new edition of the encyclopaedia "<a href="Die%20Musik%20in%20Geschichte%20und%20Gegenwart">Die Musik in Geschichte und Gegenwart</a>" in 28 volumes, for which he wrote or updated some 40 articles. His extensive works on <a href="string%20quartet">string quartet</a>s, <a href="chamber%20music">chamber music</a> and <a href="Joseph%20Haydn">Joseph Haydn</a> are regarded as musicological standards, as is the two-volume "Music of the 15th and 16th centuries".
Finscher contributed to the complete editions of the works of <a href="Christoph%20Willibald%20Gluck">Christoph Willibald Gluck</a>, <a href="Neue%20Mozart-Ausgabe">W. A. Mozart</a>, and <a href="Paul%20Hindemith">Paul Hindemith</a>. He was also co-editor of the "Capellae Apostolicae Sixtinaeque Collectanea Acta Monumenta". He published over 130 articles in anthologies and journals, aiming for simple wording accessible to lay readers as well as specialists.
